stories.title: Working with Strings in Embedded C++

stories.text:
I remember the old days of Enterprise software sales. You had face to face meetings. A sales rep in major cities and countries. Lots of flying around. Filling out RFCs and opaque pricing.

How do the brand new enterprise SaaS platforms market themselves these days? How does a Snowflake or a Figma or a Miro or a Atlassian market itself to the right people and teams?
stories.title: Ask HN: How do you market your new B2B SaaS platform?
Reconsidering where I call home: I want a three-bedroom house near a ski resort

stories.text: I‘m in a new role as an Enterprise Release Manager for a large cooperation. My job is to manage the releases of multiple software products on a variation of different hardware setups (trains). While I have some solid experience I‘d like to deepen my knowledge with some books covering this area. Release managers and fellow HNs - what is a must read on your list?
stories.title: Ask HN: Best Books on Release Management?

stories.text:
I started coding really early and I used to think I was pretty good(and maybe I was at the time), but then I burnt out and started really stagnating/regressing.

It's kind of fcking up my self esteem to see classmates who were learning a lot from me a few years ago and who are now doing better than me.

I remember a senior at my last job who after I spent a day struggling on a problem was like "ppfffft, here, i did that in 30 minutes" in a very condescending way, and looking back I'm thinking, was he an a-hole?was he right?both?

How do you know if you're decent and not some mediocre fraud?

I never know if I have impostor syndrome or dunning kruger.

I've done some projects I would consider fairly complex but they weren't great: The code quality never was amazing, the code was rarely as fast it could/should be, rarely bug free etc...

Is there any kind of objective metrics to know if you're actually decent at this?

I get interviews and jobs relatively easily, but I wonder if it's just because I oversell myself, went to a good school and recruiters are desperate
stories.title: Ask HN: How to know if you're a decent programmer?
